newsitem.title: LUXEMBOURG: EX KB LUX STAFF GIVEN HEAVY FINES.
newsitem.headline: EX KB LUX STAFF GIVEN HEAVY FINES.

text.p: A Luxembourg court on Wednesday gave two former employees of Kredietbank (KB) Luxembourg heavy fines and prison sentences for computer fraud, receiving stolen goods and fraud, legal sources said.
One of the two men was sentenced to three years in prison and a fine of one million Luxembourg francs. The other got 30 months in jail and a 800,000 franc fine.
The prison terms will be reduced by time already served in detention, which is two years for both men.

The two were among five employees fired by the bank, a unit of Belgium's Almanij holding company, at the start of 1994 after allegedly fraudulent actions, in particular illegally transferring 20 million marks ($13.1 million) in funds to accounts in eastern Europe, were detected.
KB Luxembourg says it has recovered around 18.3 million marks.
The public prosecutor demanded five-year prison sentences for both.
Their lawyers claimed the court was not competent to rule on the charge of receiving stolen goods since the offence was allegedly committed in Slovakia. They asked for their acquittal.
The three others are not being prosecuted under Luxembourg law because they are residents of neighbouring Belgium, which does not extradite its citizens.
